details.title: A Simple Heuristic Algorithm for Generating All Minimal Paths
details.standardTitle: A Simple Heuristic Algorithm for Generating All Minimal Paths

p: Wei-Chang Yeh is currently a professor of the Department of Industrial Engineering and Management Engineering at National Tsing Hua University in Taiwan. He received his M.S., and Ph.D. from the Department of Industrial Engineering at the University of Texas at Arlington. His research interests include network reliability theory, graph theory, deadlock problem, Linear Programming, and scheduling. He is a member of the IEEE, and INFORMS.

details.abstract: Evaluating network reliability is an important topic in the planning, designing, and control of network systems. In this paper, an intuitive heuristic algorithm is developed to find all minimal paths (MP) by adding a path, or an edge into a network repeatedly until the network is equal to the original network. The proposed heuristic algorithm is easier to understand & implement than the existing known heuristic algorithm. Without generating any duplicate MP, it is also more efficient. The correctness of the proposed algorithm will be analysed, and proven. One bench example is illustrated to show how to evaluate the network reliability using the proposed heuristic algorithm.

context.text: There is no doubt th is defined here as the probability of a live connection between the source node, and the sink node. in recent years, network reliability theory has been applied extensively in many real-world systems such as computer and communication systems, power transmission and distribution systems, transportation systems, oil/gas production systems [1]–[7], etc.
Thus, the network reliability plays important roles in our modern society; and more authors have been paying attention to the network reliability problem [1]–[27].

links.abstract: A general simulation/analytic approach for jointly assessing the reliability and performance of a communication/computer network is proposed. The advantages of this approach are the following: (a) it allows consideration of a variety of performance measures, (b) it allows consideration of a general structure of network components failure distribution, (c) it reduces complexity of the model and related calculations, (d) it is relatively simple to implement, and (e) it can derive sensitivity infor...

links.abstract: The authors present a computer approach to obtaining a survivability index called capacity related reliability (CRR) in large telecommunication networks where links have different capacities. The method is a two-step approach. The first step deals with composite path enumeration (CPE). A k-composite path is defined as the union of the set of edges in any k simple paths and relates link capacity and network connectivity. The CPE approach is an improvement over the algorithms proposed by the autho...

links.abstract: This paper examines two compensating methods that: (1) account for imperfect nodes, and (2) can be embedded in most symbolic network reliability algorithms that presume perfect nodes. The Aggarwal method can be exponential in time with the number of links, whereas the Torrieri method is always linear. However the Torrieri method can yield incorrect results for some undirected networks. This paper points out such incorrectness and then proposes an efficient reliability evaluation algorithm (ENR/K...

context.text: Thus, the network reliability plays important roles in our modern society; and more authors have been paying attention to the network reliability problem [1]–[8][27].
The evaluation of network reliability is an NP-hard problem [8], [9].
However, both the problems in locating all MC/MP, and computing the exact reliability in terms of the known MC/MP, are also NP-hard [8], [9].
Enumerating all of the MP in a network is a NP-hard problem [8], [9].

references.text: M. R. Garey, D. S. Johnson, Computers and Intractability: A Guide to the Theory of NP-hardness, 1979, E.H. Freeman.

context.text: Probabilistic techniques usually associate the connectivity level of a network with the availability, and /or reliability of the communication paths between specific network node-pairs [10]–[19].

The network must satisfy the following assumptions [10]–[19]:

1)
Each node is perfectly reliable, and each edge has two states: working, or failed.

2)
The network is connected, and free of self-loops.

3)
There are no parallel branches.

4)
Degrees of all nodes are at least 2, except for the source node \$s\$, and sink node \$t\$.
Thus, the network reliability plays important roles in our modern society; and more authors have been paying attention to the network reliability problem [1]–[10][27].
Among the most popular tools are network-based algorithms founded in terms of either MC or MP [10]–[19].
To the author’s best knowledge, Al-Ghanim first investigated a heuristic programming algorithm to generate all MP [10].

He first created a path, then used an iterative method by tracing back from an explored node in the current path via unexplored nodes to the source node, and swapped the sub-paths in the corresponding MP to generate new MP [10].

The main concepts behind the existing heuristic algorithm [10], and the proposed algorithm to search for all MP are:

6)
Construct the initial network \$G_{0}\$, find the MP set \$P^{0}\$ in \$G_{0}\$, and let \$\lambda=1\$.

7)
Find the new MP set \$P^{\lambda+1}\$ in the updated network \$G_{\lambda+1}=G_{\lambda}\oplus b_{xy}\$, where \$b_{xy}\wedge G_{\lambda}=\{x,y\}\$, and \$b_{xy}\cap G_{\lambda}=\varnothing\$; let \$\lambda=\lambda+1\$, and \$P^{(\lambda)}=P^{(\lambda-1)}\cup P^{\lambda }\$.

8)
Repeat the above Procedure 2 until the current network \$G_{\lambda}\$ is equal to the original network \$G\$.

To compare the proposed algorithm with the best-known heuristic method presented in [10], the main calculation procedure, i.e. procedure 2, of the best-known heuristic method for finding new MP is listed by transforming into our notation.

Hence, \$\vert P\vert \leq {\rm Min}\{\sum_{i=I}^{\vert V\vert}{\vert E\vert\choose i}, 2^{\vert V\vert}(\vert V\vert !)\}\$, and the time complexity is \$O({\rm Min}\{\sum_{i=I}^{\vert V\vert}{\vert E\vert \choose i}, 2^{\vert V\vert}(\vert V\vert !))\$ to find all MP [10], where \$I\$ is the number of arcs in the shortest path.

Because \$\lambda+\vert P_{0}\vert \ll\vert E\vert\$, and \$\vert V^{\ast}\vert \leq \vert V^{\ast}\vert\$, the proposed algorithm is more efficient than the existing known algorithm proposed in [10].

The proposed heuristic algorithm is more efficient than the existing known algorithm proposed in [10] for locating all MP in a network without any duplicate in time complexity \$O({\rm Min}\{\sum_{i=I}^{\vert V\vert}{\lambda^{\ast}+\vert P_{0}\vert \choose i}, 2^{\vert V^{\ast}\vert}(\vert V^{\ast}\vert !))\$, where \$\lambda^{\ast}\$ is the last value of \$\lambda\$ in STEP 3, and \$\vert V^{\ast}\vert\$ is the total number of the set of all endpoints in the paths found in STEP 4 of the proposed algorithm.

Owing to this inherent problem, instead of presenting practically large network systems, a moderate size benchmark network called the modified ARPANET shown in Fig. 1, which is the most frequently cited example [10]–[19], was selected to demonstrate this methodology. in this illustrative network, each edge represents a transmission line, and consists of several physical transmission lines, e.g.
Nevertheless, there is only one heuristic approach for searching for all MP [10].

references.title:
A heuristic technique for generating minimal
path and cutsets of a general network
references.text: A. M. Al-Ghanim, "A heuristic technique for generating minimal path and cutsets of a general network", Computers & Industrial Engineering, vol. 36, pp. 45-55, 1999.

context.text: Probabilistic techniques usually associate the connectivity level of a network with the availability, and /or reliability of the communication paths between specific network node-pairs [10]–[11][19].

The network must satisfy the following assumptions [10]–[11][19]:

1)
Each node is perfectly reliable, and each edge has two states: working, or failed.

2)
The network is connected, and free of self-loops.

3)
There are no parallel branches.

4)
Degrees of all nodes are at least 2, except for the source node \$s\$, and sink node \$t\$.
Thus, the network reliability plays important roles in our modern society; and more authors have been paying attention to the network reliability problem [1]–[11][27].
Among the most popular tools are network-based algorithms founded in terms of either MC or MP [10]–[11][19].
There is generally a need to evaluate only a few of the modifications in an existing network for expansion or reinforcement without relocating all MP or MC [11]–[14].
Such problems have been solved recently for MP [11], [12], and MC [13], [14], separately.

Based on the important result from our previous published paper [11], to search for all MP in a new network using the MP obtained in the network before adding a path, a new heuristic algorithm is proposed to search for all new MP by adding repeatedly a new path (arc) to a network until the original network (see Fig. 1) is formed completely.
The following theorem is first proposed in [11].

Then, \$[\Pi_{X:Y}(P_{XY}^{(\lambda)})\otimes B_{XY}]\cup [\Pi_{sX}(P_{X \backslash Y}^{(\lambda)})\otimes B_{XY}\$\$\otimes\Pi_{Yt}(P_{Y \backslash X}^{(\lambda)})]\cup[\Pi_{Y:X}(P_{YX}^{(\lambda)})\otimes B_{YX}]\$\$\cup[\Pi_{sY}(P_{Y \backslash X}^{(\lambda)})\otimes B_{YX}\otimes \Pi_{Xt}(P_{X \backslash Y}^{(\lambda)})]\$ are all new MP in \$G_{\lambda+1}=G_{\lambda}\oplus b_{xy}\$ [11].

To prevent any duplicate MP before it is generated from Situations 1 & 2, a new notation “\$P_{\underline{xy}}\$” is proposed to replace “\$P_{xy}\$” (which is defined in [11] using notation \$P_{x\rightarrow y}\$): \$p_{i}\in P_{\underline{xy}}\$ iff \$p_{i}\in P_{xy}\$, \$\pi_{sx}(p_{i})\not\in\Pi_{sx}(P_{x\backslash y})\$, and \$\pi_{yt}(p_{i})\not\in\Pi_{yt}(P_{y\backslash x})\$.

Owing to this inherent problem, instead of presenting practically large network systems, a moderate size benchmark network called the modified ARPANET shown in Fig. 1, which is the most frequently cited example [10]–[11][19], was selected to demonstrate this methodology. in this illustrative network, each edge represents a transmission line, and consists of several physical transmission lines, e.g.

The network must satisfy the following assumptions [10]–[18][19]:

1)
Each node is perfectly reliable, and each edge has two states: working, or failed.

2)
The network is connected, and free of self-loops.

3)
There are no parallel branches.

4)
Degrees of all nodes are at least 2, except for the source node \$s\$, and sink node \$t\$.
Thus, the network reliability plays important roles in our modern society; and more authors have been paying attention to the network reliability problem [1]–[18][27].
Among the most popular tools are network-based algorithms founded in terms of either MC or MP [10]–[18][19].

Owing to this inherent problem, instead of presenting practically large network systems, a moderate size benchmark network called the modified ARPANET shown in Fig. 1, which is the most frequently cited example [10]–[18][19], was selected to demonstrate this methodology. in this illustrative network, each edge represents a transmission line, and consists of several physical transmission lines, e.g.

context.text: Probabilistic techniques usually associate the connectivity level of a network with the availability, and /or reliability of the communication paths between specific network node-pairs [10]–[19].

The network must satisfy the following assumptions [10]–[19]:

1)
Each node is perfectly reliable, and each edge has two states: working, or failed.

2)

There are no parallel branches.

links.abstract: Many systems can be regarded as flow networks whose arcs have discrete and multi-valued random capacities. The probability of the maximum flow at each various level and the reliability of such a flow network can be calculated in terms of K-lattices which are generated from each subset of the family of all MCs (minimal cutsets). links.abstract: Many real-world systems are multistate and composed of multistate components in which the reliability can be computed in terms of the lower bound points of level d, called d-minpaths (d-MP). Such systems (electric power, transportation, etc.) may be regarded as flow networks whose arcs have statistically independent, discrete, limited and multivalued random capacities. This study focuses on how to find the entire path of d-MP before calculating the reliability of an acyclic network. Analysis of ...

links.abstract: In this paper, we propose a definition of the dominant multi-state system. Under the proposed definition, multi-state systems are divided into two groups without reference to component relevancy conditions: dominant systems, and nondominant systems. Dominant systems can be further divided into two groups: with binary image, and without binary image. A multi-state system with binary image implies that its structure function can be expressed in terms of binary structure functions such that it can ...

links.abstract: This paper presents an overview of results related to the computational complexity of network reliability analysis problems. Network reliability analysis problems deal with the determination of reliability measures for stochastic networks. We show how these problems are related to the more familiar computational network problems of recognizing certain subnetworks, finding optimal subnetworks, and counting certain subnetworks. We use these relationships to show that the k-terminal, the 2-terminal...
